'''Île-à-Vache''', ([[French language|French]], also expressed '''Île-à-Vaches''', former [[Spanish language|Spanish]] name '''Isla Vaca''', all translate to '''Cow Island''') is a [[Caribbean]] island, one of [[Haiti]]'s satellite islands. It lies in the Baie de Cayes about {{convert|6.5|mi|km}} off the coast of the country's southwest peninsula, roughly between the town of [[Les Cayes]] and Pointe l'Abacou. It was formerly known by the name of Abacca. Administratively, it became a [[List of communes of Haiti|commune]] in 1976 as part of the [[Les Cayes Arrondissement]] in the [[Sud (department)|Sud]] [[Departments of Haiti|department]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Communes de la République d'Haiti | url = http://www.gexperthaiti.com/haiti/Site/Communes.htm | author = Haitian Institute of Statistics and Informatics (IHSI) | year = 1998}}</ref>
Île-à-Vache was claimed by the Spanish Empire in 1492 as part of [[Hispaniola]], and for the next two centuries it was known by the name Isla Vaca. In 1697 the island of Hispaniola was formally divided between Spain and France in the [[Treaty of Ryswick]] which ended the [[Nine Years War]]. France assumed control of the western half of Hispaniola and named it [[Saint-Domingue]], and Isla Vaca took on its current name, Île-à-Vache.
==Geography== The island is about {{convert|8|mi|km}} long and {{convert|2|mi|km}} wide, with an area of {{convert|20|sqmi|km2}}. The western end of the island has rolling hills with elevations as high as {{convert|490|ft|m}} with several small [[swamp]]s in the valleys; the eastern side of the island is swampy, and contains a [[lagoon]] with one of the largest [[mangrove]] forests in Haiti.<ref>{{cite news | author = T. Brooks & L.M. Davalos | title = The Birds of Île-à-Vache, Haiti | year = 2001 | publisher = Caribbean Journal of Science}}</ref> The island is also surrounded by several dangerous shoals, reefs, and rocks that have been the cause of many shipwrecks throughout history,<ref>{{cite book | author = [[Médéric Louis Élie Moreau de Saint-Méry|Moreau de Saint-Méry, Médéric Louis Élie]] | title = Description topographique, physique, civile, politique et historique de la partie française de l'isle Saint-Domingue | year = 1797–1798}}</ref> including that of the famous Canadian fishing and racing [[schooner]] ''[[Bluenose]]'', which was wrecked on the island in 1946.
==Demographics== The population of the island in 2015 was 14,004 adult inhabitants.<ref>{{cite web | title = Population totale, population de 18 ans et plus menages et densites estimes en 2009 | publisher = Haitian Institute of Statistics and Informatics (IHSI) | year = 2009 | url = http://www.ihsi.ht/pdf/projection/POPTOTAL&MENAGDENS_ESTIM2009.pdf | accessdate = 2014-05-29 }}</ref> Île-à-Vache is one of the most popular tourist sites in Haiti and it has some of the best island scenery in the [[Caribbean]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} There are two tourist resorts on the island, Port Morgan and Abaka Bay.
==History== ===Henry Morgan=== The pirate captain [[Henry Morgan]] (c.1635–1688) frequently used the little island as a base for his operations.{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=48}}{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=50}} Morgan planned and staged many of his largest raids from Isla Vaca, and lost multiple ships in the island's waters which have recently been found and explored by research divers. [[File:Captain Henry Morgan.jpg|thumb|Captain [[Henry Morgan]].]] In January 1669, Morgan brought ten ships and 800 men to Isla Vaca as a rendezvous point before launching a raid on the Spanish city of [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]]. Because he and his fellow buccaneers had just captured two French warships, they decided to celebrate in the easily accessible Ferret Bay on the northwest side of the island. They made a fire to roast several pigs and fired the cannons of their flagship as was typical for a buccaneer celebration. In the midst of their drunken revelry, the ship's gunpowder magazine was accidentally lit, triggering an explosion that blew up Morgan's flagship ''Oxford''. In the explosion, Morgan, who was on board the ship, was thrown through the window of his quarters and into the sea. He survived the accident, but the ''Oxford'' sank, taking down with it the two captured French warships (which were tied to it) and about 200 of his men.{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=48}}{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=49}}
The ship, which was only {{convert|4|m}} below the water's surface, was found in 2004 by a team of researchers. They were accompanied by a team from the Welsh television channel S4C, which has made a documentary of the discovery. If there is still spoil located on board, is not yet known.
In 1675-1676 he again narrowly survived a costly shipwreck on the island's shores. Morgan had been appointed Lieutenant Governor of Jamaica and was on his way from England to take up the post. He possibly headed for Isla Vaca to salvage what he could from the sunken ships of the 1669 incident.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} But a storm arose and sank his ship ''Jamaica Merchant'', which was loaded with a full complement of cannon which he had been bringing to bolster the defenses at [[Port Royal]].{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=54}}{{sfn|Cordingly|1996|p=55}} This ship has been found by researchers, who have recovered dishes, bronze coins, and the ship's anchor.
The current tourist resort of Port Morgan is named after him.
From 1682-1684 French pirate [[Jean Hamlin]] used the island as his hideout while plundering English and Dutch ships.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lane|first1=Kris E.|title=Blood and Silver: A History of Piracy in the Caribbean and Central America|date=1999|publisher=Signal Books|location=Oxford UK|isbn=9781902669014|pages=128-129|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7FeDivv4UsEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=17 August 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Bernard Kock=== [[File:Bernard Kock 5 Haitian dollar note.jpg|thumb|Bernard Kock 5 Haitian dollar note]] [[File:Bernard Kock 2 Haitian dollar note.jpg|thumb|Bernard Kock 2 Haitian dollar note]]
In 1862 the entrepreneur Bernard Kock, who owned a Florida cotton plantation, visited the [[The Great Exhibition|World Fair]] in London. When he saw two bales of cotton from Haiti, he was impressed by the quality and immediately saw a business opportunity. He was an ardent [[abolitionism|abolitionist]], but he believed that after they were freed, former slaves had to have meaningful work. Therefore, he conceived the plan to develop Île-à-Vache by sending 5,000 emancipated slaves from the United States to grow cotton there.
He left for Haiti on May 17, 1862 and arrived in [[Jacmel]] on June 3. From there he went on horseback to [[Port-au-Prince]], where he was warmly received by the president of the country, [[Fabre Geffrard]]. The negotiations were difficult, however. On the one hand, the president supported the arrival of more blacks to the country, but he was also reluctant to rent a piece of Haitian soil to a white man.
Still, Kock managed to sign a contract on August 8 which granted him a 10 year lease of Île-à-Vache, with the right to an extension of a further 10 years. The rent was 3.5 [[Haitian gourde|gourdes]] (about $0.35) per hectare. He had to start operations within six months and a number of employee supervisors had to be black. They would be immediately naturalized as Haitians upon arrival. Kock was to provide a percentage of all the wood that he chopped on the island, as a kind of tax. The contract also guaranteed that he would protect the Haitian state, and that he would not have to pay import duties on the supplies that he imported.
During the same period, the United States was embroiled in the [[American Civil War]] and President [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln]], who was in favor of the abolition of slavery, was considering plans to establish "colonies" of emancipated slaves in countries like New Granada and Liberia where they could live and work. He even offered $50 to anyone who took a black person abroad and gave him a job there.
Kock left on August 14 for New York, and arrived on August 28. However, the [[United States Secretary of State|American Secretary of State]], [[William H. Seward|William Seward]], had received many complaints from Central American governments who saw no advantage in the advent of so many blacks to their region. In light of these complaints, Seward stalled Kock's plan.
So Kock went directly to President Lincoln. Lincoln had his doubts about Kock's sincerity at first. He suspected that Kock was only after the $50 per person which had been promised. Kock managed to convince him, however, and on December 31, the President promised that he would think about his plan. But just one day later, on January 1, 1863, Lincoln signed the [[Emancipation Proclamation]], which contained not a single word about this or any other colonial plan.
Disappointed, Kock moved to Washington. There, he managed to find some blacks who were interested in going to Haiti. Back in New York, he found three financiers who pledged $70,000 to his venture. On the basis of this pledge, Koch chartered the British ship the ''Ocean Ranger'' and with this ship he brought 500 people to Île-à-Vache on April 13, 1863. Some of his passengers became ill from [[smallpox]] while on board, forcing Kock to found a small emergency hospital upon arrival.
Kock closed with laborers on a 4-year contract for a wage of $0.16 per day, costs included. He printed special Gourde notes, upon which read the text ''Island of A'Vache'' {{sic}} and his own name, Bernard Kock. These were exchangeable for normal Haitian gourdes.
The financiers, however, did not fulfill their promise. They still paid the initial amount, partly in hopes of reaping the promised $50 per person. This reward remained in effect because the government continued to doubt Koch's good intentions. After the reward was given, the financiers sent scarcely any more money or supplies to the island. The workers found themselves in rebellion, and Koch had to call in 15 Haitian soldiers for help in controlling the situation. In addition, the financiers made increasing demands, which Koch could not meet without money and goods.
Ultimately, the contract was broken. On December 22, 1863 President Lincoln sent a ship to Haiti to bring the remaining 453 workers back to the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.numismondo.net/pm/hti/bernardkock/ |title=HAÏTI Paper Money, Bernard Kock Issues, Ca. 1863 |year=1863 |access-date=29 May 2014 |first=Richard H. |last=Ponterio |publisher=Garry Saint, Esquire |work=Numismondo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thompsongenealogy.com/2011/12/bernard-kock-colonized-cow-island-with-freed-slaves/ |title=Bernard Kock Colonized Cow Island With Freed Slaves |date=December 2011 |access-date=29 May 2014 |last=Thompson |first=Boyce |work=Thompson Family History |publisher=Boyce Thompson Media, LLC}}</ref>
===Current times=== The best-known personality on the island is Sr. Flora, a French-Canadian [[Franciscan]] nun who founded an orphanage and school which she has run for decades in the village of Madame Bernard.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soulofhaiti.ie/what-we-do/developing-sustainable-communities/ile-a-vache-orphanage-community-programme/ |work=Soul of Haiti |title=Ile a Vache Orphanage & Community Programme |author=Sr Flora |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429051401/http://www.soulofhaiti.ie/what-we-do/developing-sustainable-communities/ile-a-vache-orphanage-community-programme/ |archive-date=29 April 2014 |publisher=LPHmedia ltd.}}</ref>
The Haitian government has announced plans to begin an international touristic destination project on the island of Île-à-Vache. The government’s projects on the island has launched with plans for 1,000 luxury hotel rooms, an archaeology museum, nightclubs, art galleries and craft boutiques. Since its commencement in 2013 to its projected completion in late 2015, this makes Île-à-Vache among the largest ongoing tourism projects in the Caribbean.<ref name=Staff>{{cite web |url=http://caribjournal.com/2014/08/30/haiti-planning-to-develop-1000-hotel-rooms-on-ile-a-vache/ |title=Haiti Planning to Develop 1,000 Hotel Rooms on Ile a Vache |work=Caribbean Journal |date=30 August 2014 |access-date=20 July 2018 |author=Staff}}</ref>
The government has built a 2.6-kilometre runway with plans for an international airport.<ref name=Staff/>
As of February 2014, the Haitian government has begun the process of expropriation and relocation.<ref>HA/radio Métropole Haiti</ref>
